Scheme 44 Direct catalytic synthesis of functionalized dienes from simple 1,3-dienes: A review on substitution of 1,3-butadiene, isoprene, and 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene with metal catalysts Yukio Hamamoto Writing – original draft Investigation Conceptualization Yasushi Obora Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Investigation Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Department of Chemistry and Materials Engineering, Faculty of Chemistry, Materials and Bioengineering, Kansai University, Suita, Osaka 5648680, Japan Department of Chemistry and Materials Engineering, Faculty of Chemistry, Materials and Bioengineering, Kansai University Suita Osaka 5648680 Japan Department of Chemistry and Materials Engineering, Faculty of Chemistry, Materials and Bioengineering, Kansai University, Suita, Osaka, 5648680, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Conjugated diene structures are important as feedstocks for many organic reactions. Therefore, development of efficient syntheses of conjugated diene compounds is desirable. This review introduces selective functionalizing reactions to 1,3-butadiene, isoprene, 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene with various metal catalysts, ligands, and types of reactions. To overcome difficulties of controlling reactions, Heck reactions with Pd or Ni catalysts and metathesis cross couplings with Grubbs catalysts are mainly used. Focused on ligands, phosphines, 1,5-cyclooctadiene, imidazoline derivatives are frequently used. As a plausible mechanism, formation of π-allyl complexes is concerned as an initial step, especially when palladium is used. Then, as an intermediate, η2-π-allyl metal are formed. At last, reductive elimination undergoes and the desired compounds are obtained. Reaction mechanisms are concerned by labelling experiment or isolation of intermediates in most examples. In addition, in most reactions, results of substrate scope that not only 1,3-butadiene, isoprene, 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene are used are depicted. Besides, several applications of functionalized dienes are introduced. As a result, synthesized dienes are converted into (hetero)cyclic compounds, polyenes, enyl ketones. Overall, diene is considered a useful starting material for addition reactions such as polymerization, telomerization, and annulation and functionalizing dienes is expected to facilitate the efficient synthesis of organic compounds with complex structures by upgrading simple 1,3-diene. Graphical Abstract Keywords Conjugated diene 1,3-butadiene Isoprene 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene Functionalized 1,3-diene Upgrading feedstock Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Efficient preparation of high-value chemicals is important to many chemists. Organic compounds bearing conjugated diene structures are valuable feedstocks for key reactions, such as telomerization [1–21], Diels–Alder reactions [22–38] and aromatic cyclization [39–52] ( Scheme 1 (a)). Our research group has been investigating silylation [53–60], stannylation [53], amination [58–60], and alkoxylation [57] using two carbon–carbon double bonds in 1,3-dienes (Scheme 1 (b)). Conventional methods for synthesizing conjugated dienes include cross couplings between alkynes and alkenes and silylation of unsaturated carbonyl compounds, dimerization of allene (Scheme 1 (c)). For example, Schüth’s group [61] reported cross-metathesis reaction between acetylene and ethylene with Grubbs catalyst. Kitahara and Danishefsky [62] achieved direct silyl enol etherification of hexamethyldisilane and trans-4-methoxybutene-2-one, synthesizing dienes known as Danishefsky–Kitahara diene. In addition, Hegedus et al. [63] used propadiene as the substrate and palladium and copper chloride as the catalysts. However, each reaction has disadvantages, for instance, difficulties of storing and treating starting materials and limited range of applications. Although conjugated dienes have attracted much attention, there are few reports on catalytic synthesis of conjugated dienes from dienes. This review introduces recent catalytic methods that use commercially available 1,3-dienes, such as 1,3-butadiene, isoprene, and 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene. These reactions are beneficial for upgrading feedstocks. In Section 2.1, we provide examples of dimerization of these 1,3-dienes. In Section 2.2, we describe the functionalization of the sp2 carbon atoms of 1,3-dienes. In Section 2.3, we discuss the introduction of functional groups into the sp3 carbon atoms of the methyl groups of isoprene and 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene. Section 3 contains our concluding remarks. 2 Catalytic reactions for upgrading 1,3-dienes to valuable feedstocks 2.1 Preparation of 1,3-diene derivatives by dimerization Dimerization of 1,3-dienes has attracted much attention because the reaction is an important, efficient method for synthesizing olefins, including conjugated diene structures. Although olefins are valuable for industry, few methods have been reported. In 2017, Mancheño’s [64] group reported Pd-catalyzed highly selective isoprene tail-to-tail dimerization ( Scheme 2). They used Pd(II) acetate (Pd(OAc)2) (1 mol%) as the catalyst, triphenylphosphine (PPh3) (3 mol%) as the additive, triethylamine (NEt3) (10 mol%) as the base, and tetrahydrofuran (THF) (10 mL) as the solvent. The reaction time was 48 h and the temperature was 90 °C. The yield of 2,7-dimethyl-1,3,7-octatriene was 85 % and the selectivity was 94 %. They proposed the following reaction mechanism ( Scheme 3) [64]. Firstly, Pd(OAc)2 was reduced to Pd(0) by triethylamine and triphenylphosphine. Secondly, two isoprene complexed Pd(0) (A). Then, the tail-to-tail attack occurred, and a Pd(η1,η3-dimethyloctadiendiyl) complex (B) was formed. The Pd complex was protonated with acetic acid, forming the cationic intermediate (C). After the π-allyl–Pd(II) cation (D) was formed followed by the β-hydrogen elimination with NEt3 to form the η2-alkene Pd(0), Pd(η2,η2-dimethyloctatriene) complex (E). Finally, the desired triene left Pd and two other isoprene coordinated to Pd(0), beginning the catalytic reaction again. In this reaction, the acetate catalyst was key to obtaining good yields of the dimers. An important use of dienes is as building blocks for heterocyclic compounds via a Diels–Alder reaction [64]. The synthesis of heterocycles from 2,7-dimethyl-1,3,7-octatriene has been reported. The reaction was upscaled to 50 mmol (5 times), and the yield of 2,7-dimethyl-1,3,7-octatriene was 70 % under the same conditions as on the smaller scale. Heterocycles were prepared from formaldehyde, maleic acid derivatives, and iminoiodinanes. The conditions and results are shown in Scheme 4. A hetero Diels–Alder reaction was used to synthesise 5,6-dihydro-4-methyl-2-(3-methyl-3-buten-1-yl)-2H-pyran from the reaction of diene and formaldehyde. The pyran was obtained with a yield of 64 %. 2,7-Dimethyl-1,3,7-octatriene also underwent a Diels–Alder reaction with maleic anhydride, N-methylmaleimide and N-phenylmaleimide. The yield of each Diels–Alder product was over 80 %. A [4 + 1] cycloaddition was achieved with 2,7-dimethyl-1,3,7-octatriene and (tosylimino)phenyliodinane. The yield of 2,5-dihydro-4-methyl-2-(3-methyl-3-buten-1-yl)-1-[(4-methylphenyl)sulfonyl]-1H-pyrrole was 71 % (Scheme 4). Beller [65,66] and co-workers reported highly chemoselective dimerization of 1,3-butadiene with Pd catalysts. The best reaction conditions were 1,3-bis(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)-4,5-dimethyl-3H-imidazolidenylpalladium (0) (0.005 mol%) as the catalyst, isopropanol (2 equiv) as the co-catalyst, sodium isopropoxide (NaO i Pr) (1 mol%) as the base, and THF (3 mL) as the solvent. The dimer was obtained in 92 % yield and 95 % selectivity at 70 °C in 48 h ( Scheme 5). They also proposed a mechanism for the dimerization [65,66]. Two 1,3-butadiene molecules complexed 1,3-bis(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)-4,5-dimethyl-3H-imidazolidenylpalladium (0). Dimerization occurred, and a Pd carbenoid was formed. The Pd complex was then protonated with isopropanol to form the cationic intermediate. Before or after the formation of 1-isopropoxy-2,7-octadienylpalladium, the desired triene left Pd and two further 1,3-butadiene molecules coordinated to Pd(0), beginning the catalytic reaction again. In this reaction, isopropanol was an appropriate proton donor ( Scheme 6). Mortreux [67–70] and co-workers achieved chemo-, regio-, and stereoselective dimerization of 1,3-dienes with Ni complexes bearing aminophosphinite ligands. They used a Ni complex coordinated to an ephedrine derivative for the dimerization of 1,3-butadiene in toluene at 70 °C. The diene conversion was 95 % and the selectivities of 1,3,6-octatriene, and 2,4,6-octatriene were 91 %, and 3 % ( Scheme 7). They applied the Ni complex to the dimerization of other 1,3-dienes, such as isoprene, 1,3-pentadiene, methyl (2E)-2,4-pentadienoate, and methyl (2E)-2,4-hexadienoate [67–70]. The best reaction conditions and results are shown in Scheme 8. The conversion of isoprene was 95 % and it was the best result of the four examples, albeit the selectivity for diene was medium or low. The conversion of 1,3-pentadiene was 75 %, with a 91 % selectivity for 4,5-dimethyl-1,3,6-triene. From methyl (2E)-2,4-pentadienoate, dimers were obtained exclusively, with a total dimer yield of 98 %. Using methyl (2E)-2,4-hexadienoate also resulted in the high conversion and the selectivity for dimers (Scheme 8). They proposed a reaction mechanism based on labelling experiments [67–70]. Two diene molecules formed a complex with Ni and oxidative dimerization occurred. Then, the dimer was protonated by NH in the ligand and the nitrogen was coordinated to the Ni(II). Finally, two new diene molecules formed a complex with Ni and the desired dimer was eliminated. In this reaction, the NH group functioned as a hydrogen donor ( Scheme 9). Although this reaction has frequently been performed with complexes as catalysts, Bertozzi [71] et al. used Ni vapor as a catalyst for dimerizing 1,3-butadiene and isoprene. In the reaction using 1,3-butadiene, Ni vapor (0.8 mmol) was co-condensed with 1,3-butadiene (400 mmol) and ethanol (15 mL) at −196 °C. The matrix was heated to −70 °C, and tricyclohexylphosphine (PCy3) (0.8 mmol) was added. The mixture was stirred at 25 °C for 24 h. The conversion of the diene was 82 % and the stereoselectivity for (E)-1,3,7-octatriene was 70 % ( Scheme 10). When isoprene was used instead of 1,3-butadiene, the conversion of isoprene was 80 % and the selectivity for (E)-3,6-dimethyl-1,3,7-octatriene was 55 %, whereas the selectivity for (E)-2,6-dimethyl-1,3,7-octatriene was 25 % [71] ( Scheme 11). In summary, oxidative Heck reaction is a main method for dimerizing 1,3-dienes. In discussed dimerization, a protonation step was concerned as a plausible mechanism. As the intermediates, π-allyl metal(II) complexes were proposed. As the ligands, phosphines were mainly used to stabilize complexes. In all examples, geometric selectivity was medium or high. This result was caused by elimination of terminal proton with nucleophiles (e.g. alkoxide and aminide). 2.2 Functionalization of sp2 carbon in 1,3-dienes via cross-coupling reactions Although there are many examples of cross couplings with 1,3-dienes, it is extremely difficult to synthesize olefins containing a conjugated diene structure from easily available 1,3-dienes. This synthesis needs strict control of the reaction conditions. This section describes the Mizoroki–Heck reaction (Section 2.1.1) and other approaches (Section 2.2.2). 2.2.1 Preparation of conjugated dienes via a Mizoroki–Heck reaction He, Feng, and Lin’s [72] group reported Pd-catalyzed highly stereoselective preparation of a conjugated olefin from isoprene. They used Pd(OAc)2 (5 mol%) as the catalyst, tris(2-methoxyphenyl)phosphine (P(2-PhOMe)3) (10 mol%) as the additive, cesium pivalate (CsOPiv) (10 mol%) as the base, and 1,4-dioxane (2 mL) as the solvent. The reaction time was 7 h, the temperature was 70 °C, and the reaction was performed in the dark. The yield of 1,2-diphenyl-5-methyl-1,3,5-octatriene was 31 %. In this reaction, Pd species was indirectly alkenylated via 1,4-Pd migration ( Scheme 12). They explored the scope of the reaction with 1-aryl-1,3-butadiene and 1,3-nonadiene substrates [72]. Except for 1,3-nonane, the reaction conditions were the same as for isoprene. The results are shown in Schemes 13 and 1,1,6-triphenyl-1,3,5-hexatriene and 1-[(1E,3E)-6,6-diphenyl-1,3,5-hexatrien-1-yl]-4-methylbenzene were obtained in 98 % yield. The yield of 1-[(1E,3E)-6,6-diphenyl-1,3,5-hexatrien-1-yl]-4-methoxybenzene was 90 %. However, using 1-(1E)-1,3-butadien-1-yl-4-chlorobenzene and 1-(1E)-1,3-butadien-1-yl-4-fluorobenzene resulted in the medium yield. Using 1,3-nonadiene also resulted in the medium yield. Aryl dienes were better substrates for this reaction than alkyl dienes. (Scheme 13). Rowley, Blacquiere, and Newman’s [73] group reported a Pd-catalyzed highly regioselective cross coupling with isoprene and aryl triflate. The reaction conditions were isoprene (1.5 mmol) and aryl triflate, 1-bromo-3-[(trifluoromethyl)sulfonyl]benzene and 4-[(trifluoromethyl)sulfonyl]-1,1′-biphenyl (0.2 mmol) as the substrates, a cationic Pd complex bearing a 1,5-diaza-3,7-diphosphacyclooctane derivative ligand (4 mol%) as the precatalyst, 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine (TMP) (2 equiv) as the additive, and toluene (2 mL) as the solvent. A regioselectivity of up to > 95 % was obtained after 16 h at 100 °C ( Scheme 14). In this reaction, the phenyl group directly bonding to a P atom helped to achieve the high regioselectivity. Chen’s [74] group reported the Mizoroki–Heck cross-coupling reaction of 1,3-butadienes with a Ni catalyst ( Scheme 15). They used 1-iodo-4-methoxybenzene (0.2 mmol) and 1,3-butadiene (0.6 mmol) as substrates, Ni(dppe)Cl2 (dppe = 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane) (10 mol%) as the catalyst, Mn (1 equiv) and sodium chloride (3 equiv) as additives, NEt3 (0.056 mL) as the base, and acetonitrile (MeCN) (0.5 mL) as the solvent. The yield of 1-(4-methoxyphenyl)-1,3-butadiene was 32 % after 24 h at 80 °C. They also applied the Ni complex to cross-coupling reactions of other 1,3-dienes with 1-iodo-4-methoxybenzene [74]. Examples using aryl dienes and isoprene are shown in Scheme 16. They used 1-phenyl-1,3-diene, 1-(1E)-1,3-butadien-1-yl-4-aminobenzene 1-(1E)-1,3-butadien-1-yl-4-methylbenzene, 1-(1E)-1,3-butadien-1-yl-4-fuluorobenzene 1-(1E)-1,3-butadien-1-yl-4-aminobenzene, and 1-(1E)-1,3-butadien-1-yl-4-(trifluoromethyl)benzene as 1-aryl-1,3-butadienes. The yield of 4-[4-(4-methoxyphenyl)-1,3-butadien-1-yl]-benzenamine was the best yield of 83 %. The yield of the others 1-aryl-1,3-butadienes was medium. They also used isoprene and (2-methyl-1,3-butadien-1-yl)benzene. The results were medium or low yield (Scheme 16). They proposed a reaction mechanism based on labelling experiments ( Scheme 17) [74]. Ni(II) was reduced by Mn and NEt3, and then oxidative addition of 1-iodo-4-methoxybenzene to Ni(0) occurred. 1,3-Butadiene underwent carbon metalation, and subsequently the desired compound was obtained through β-hydrogen elimination. Finally, reductive elimination of hydrogen iodide occurred, completing the cycle. In this reaction, manganese and NEt3 worked as reductants. They used the reaction to upgrade 1-(4-methoxyphenyl)-1,3-butadiene through regioselective additions to 1- and 2- sp2 carbon ( Scheme 18) [74]. They used 1-iodo-4-methoxybenzene (1 mmol) and 1,3-butadiene (3 mmol) as the substrates, Ni(dppe)Cl2 (10 mol%) as the catalyst, Mn (1 equiv) and NaCl (3 equiv) as the additives, NEt3 (0.6 mL) as the base, and MeCN (5 mL) as the solvent. The yield of 1-(4-methoxyphenyl)-1,3-butadiene was 36 % at 80 °C after 24 h. 4-Iodophenyl triflate (0.6 mmol) was reacted with 1-(4-methoxyphenyl)-1,3-butadiene (0.4 mmol) to give the aryl triflate in 68 % yield. Finally, the aryl triflate (0.2 mmol) was reacted with 1,2-diphenyl-1,3-butadiene (0.25 mmol), with Ni(cod)2 (10 mol%) as the catalyst; 1,3-bis(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)imidazolium chloride (12 mol%), and 4-(5,5-dimethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborinan-2-yl)benzonitrile(4-CNC6H4Bneop) (20 mol%) as the ligands; Cs2CO3 (1.5 equiv) and NaF (20 mol%) as the bases; and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (0.3 mL) and hexane (20 mL) as the solvents. The yield of 1-[(1E,3E)-4-(4-methoxyphenyl)-1,3-butadien-1-yl]-4-(1-methylene-3,3-diphenyl-2-propen-1-yl)-benzene was 71 %. Using iodide resulted in addition to the terminal sp2 carbon of the aryl group, whereas using triflate resulted in functionalization of the internal sp2 carbon. In summary, the yield was approximately 30 % under using alkyl dienes, on the other hand, using phenyl dienes led to the high yield of over 60 %. That could be caused by the difference in charge imbalance and the difference in the length of conjugated system between phenyl dienes and alkyl dienes. Phenyl dienes are more electron-rich than alkyl dienes and this feature could affect the reactivity of dienes for a Mizoroki–Heck reaction. Dimerization of alkyl dienes could be one of the reasons for the low yield of the desired compounds. 2.2.2 Other approaches to functionalizing sp2 carbon in 1,3-dienes Hirano’s [75] group prepared a conjugated tetraene from 1,3-butadiene and an alkyne. The typical conditions were [Ru(η6-naphthalene)(η4-1,5-cyclooctadiene)] (20 mol%) as the catalyst, 2,9-dimethyldecane-5-yne and 1,3-butadiene as the substrates, and benzene as the solvent. The reaction time was 24 h and the temperature was 25 °C. The yield of 6,11-diisopentyl-5,7,9,11-hexadecatetraene was 85 %. 3-Isopentyl-1,3,5-decatriene was obtained as a byproduct in 13 % yield ( Scheme 19). The scope of the reaction was explored by using internal alkynes [75]. The reaction conditions were generally the same as the typical conditions, with some exceptions. The results are shown in Scheme 20. In any reactions, the yield of tetraene was medium and the yield of triene was low (Scheme 20). They proposed a reaction mechanism based on labelling experiments and isolating intermediates ( Scheme 21) [75]. The diene and alkyne coordinated to Ru(0) and oxidative coupling occurred. β-Hydrogen elimination gave the Ru(II) hydride and reductive elimination proceeded. Oxidative coupling with another alkyne molecule then occurred. Finally, new diene and alkyne molecules coordinated to Ru(0) and the desired tetraene was eliminated. In this reaction, the β-hydrogen elimination decided the stereoselectivity. Hirano’s[76,77] group also reported a cross coupling of 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene and unsaturated esters ( Scheme 22). They used unsaturated esters with Ru(0)(cod)(η4-conjugated diene)(MeCN) as the catalyst. For example, they used 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene (5 mmol) and methyl acrylate (5 mmol) as substrates, Ru(η4-cisoid-2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene)(cod)(MeCN) (2 mol%) as the catalyst, and benzene (2 mL) as the solvent at 40 °C for 4 h. Methyl (3E)-5,6-dimethyl-3,5-heptadienoate was obtained in 71 % yield, and the unconjugated diene was obtained as a byproduct in 26 % yield. Hu and Chen’s [78] group reported Ni-catalyzed regioselective cross couplings with dienes and unsaturated carbonyl compounds. For example, they used 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene (0.24 mmol) and 4-methoxy chalcone (0.2 mmol) as the substrates, Ni(cod)2 (10 mol%) as the catalyst, PCy3 (20 mol%) and 1,4-naphthoquinone (NQ) (5 mol%) as the additives, and isopropanol (1 mL) as the solvent. The desired enone was obtained in 74 % yield and > 95 % regioselectivity after 24 h ( Scheme 23). They also used other dienes and chalcones. Examples of the substrate scope are shown in Scheme 24 [78]. The reactions with 6-phenyl-1,3-butadiene and 1,3-butadiene as substrates were performed in methanol (MeOH), whereas those with 1-phenyl-1,3-butadiene as the substrate were performed in tert-butanol at 80 °C (Scheme 24). They proposed a reaction mechanism based on labelling experiments and time course studies ( Scheme 25) [78]. The unsaturated ketone coordinated to Ni(0), oxidating Ni(0) to Ni(II). The diene and aryl ligand underwent oxidative coupled to form a metallacycle. MeOH protonated the O atom coordinated to Ni(II) and −OMe coordinated to Ni(II) instead. The desired ketone was obtained by β-hydrogen elimination and MeOH was eliminated by reductive elimination. They used the enone product, 1,3-diphenyl-4,6-heptadiene-1-one, as a substrate for alkene hydration and annulation ( Scheme 26) [78]. In the hydration reaction, Ni(cod)2 was used as the catalyst and PCy3 and pinacolborane (HBpin) were used as additives, and the enone was borated. The borate was hydrated with hydrogen peroxide, giving the product in an overall yield of 40 %. In the annulation reaction, the enone (0.15 mmol) and dibromomethane (0.45 mmol) were the substrates, Co(II) bromide (12 mol%) was the catalyst, Zn (2 equiv) and N,N′-(2,6-pyridinediyldiethylidyne)bis[2,6-bis(1-methylethyl)-benzenamine (12 mol%) were the additives, and THF (1 mL) was the solvent. The yield was 81 % and the enantiomeric excess was 78 %. The regioselectivity of the aryl dienes’ reaction was different from that of alkyl dienes because of the difference in charge imbalance between the aryl and alkyl dienes. Grubbs’s [79] group also reported substitution of dienes with Ru catalysts called Grubbs catalysts ( Scheme 27 ). Isoprene (0.64 mmol) was borated with 4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-2-vinyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolane (0.32 mmol), the second-generation Grubbs catalyst (5 mol%), and dichlorobutane (1 mL) as the solvent at 40 °C for 12 h. They also performed the reaction with 3-methyl-1,3-pentadiene to explore the substrate scope [79]. The conditions were the same, except that the substrate ratio was 1:1. 4,4,5,5-Tetramethyl-2-[(1E)-3-methyl-1,3-pentadien-1-yl]-1,3,2-dioxaborolane was obtained with a yield of 80 % ( Scheme 28). They also reported esterification of 3-methylene-1-nonene (0.29 mmol) with (2Z)-2-butene-1,4-diol 1,4-diacetate (0.58 mmol). They used the second-generation Grubbs catalyst (5 mol%) as the catalyst, and benzene (1.5 mL) as the solvent under reflux for 12 h ( Scheme 29) [79]. The yield of 4-methylene-2-decen-1-ol acetate was 73 %. This reaction proceeded via a metathesis mechanism involving the carbon-carbon double bond of the 1,3-diene and the double bond of the monene. They used this reaction to synthesize a phenyl diene from 3-methyl-1,3-pentadiene and 4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-2-vinyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolane in one pot ( Scheme 30) [79]. The diene was borated in benzene for 2 h, and then the borate underwent Pd-catalyzed Suzuki–Miyaura coupling with bromobenzene to give the phenyl diene in 45 % yield. Tadano’s [80] group performed Ru-catalyzed stereoselective ring-opening metathesis with a 1,3-diene and a cycloalkene ( Scheme 31). (1S,2S,3S,4 R)-2-(t-Butyldiphenylsilyloxy)methyl-3-methyl-7-oxabicyclo[2.2.1]hept-5-ene (0.066 mmol) and 1,3-butadiene (2 equiv) were reacted with first- or second-generation Grubbs catalysts (5 mol%) in benzene. Each reagent was dissolved and stirred in dichloromethane before use. The first-generation Grubbs catalyst gave (Z)-compounds as the major products, whereas the second-generation Grubbs catalyst gave (E)-compounds. The modest total yield of the desired compounds was due to homo-metathesis of the bicycloalkene. In general, a metathesis reaction is a familiar method for functionalization of alkene. Therefore, a few cross metathesis reactions using conjugated dienes ware reported. Unlike a Mizoroki–Heck reaction, halides were not necessary to a metathesis reaction as the substrates. Therefore, metathesis is a cleaner reaction than a Mizoroki–Heck reaction. However, a metathesis reaction has disadvantages, too, for example, it needs to use compounds include an unsaturated C–C bond as the substrates. The reaction using a Ni catalyst also resulted in the high yield. A plausible reason is stability of the metallacycle intermediates. 2.3 Substitution of sp3 carbon in 1,3-dienes via a cross-coupling reaction Dienes are widely used as polymer starting materials. However, the correct dimers are needed to synthesize the desired functional polymer selectively. Therefore, functionalization of both the sp2 carbon and sp3 carbon is important, which requires strict control of the cross-coupling reaction conditions. Carreira’s [81] group reported Ir-catalyzed highly enantioselective C-alkylation of isoprene, using [Ir(cod)Cl2] (4 mol%) as the catalyst, 5-(11bR)-dinaphtho[2,1-d:1′,2′-f][1–3]dioxaphosphepin-4-yl-5H-dibenz[b,f]azepine (16 mol%) as the ligand, N-[[3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]sulfonyl]-2,4,6-tris(1-methylethyl)-benzenesulfonamide (50 mol%) as an additive to adjust acidity in situ, and chloroform (0.5 mL) as the solvent. The reaction time was 24 h and the temperature was 25 °C. The desired trimer was obtained in 62 % yield in total and 99 % enantiomeric excess ( Scheme 32). The complex additive was used because the trifluoromethyl group regulated the acidity and the isopropyl group acted like a shield to confine allylic imidation. Kimura’s [82] group developed a Pd-catalyzed coupling reaction between 1,3-dienes and benzaldehyde. Typical conditions were isoprene (4 mmol) and benzaldehyde (1 mmol) as the substrates, Pd(OAc)2 (10 mol%) as the catalyst, Xantphos (10 mol%) as the ligand, and triethylborane (BEt3) (2 mmol) as the additive at 25 °C in 24 h under N2. The best yield of 99 % was of α-(2-methylene-3-buten-1-yl)benzenemethanol ( Scheme 33). To examine the substrate scope, they used other 1,3-dienes with benzaldehyde, and other aldehydes or an ether with isoprene ( Scheme 34) [82]. Medium to high yields were achieved for these reactions. In these reactions, aryl aldehydes bearing an electron-withdrawing group on the benzene ring gave the desired product in greater yields than electron-rich aryl aldehydes. They proposed the following reaction mechanism ( Scheme 35) [82]. Isoprene formed a complex with Pd coordinated to Xantphos to form a 4π-allyl Pd species. Benzaldehyde coordinated to the borane was oxidatively coupled with isoprene, and Pd(0) was oxidized. The ethyl group on the borane coordinated to the Pd(II) center, and then ethane and the desired alcohol derivative were obtained by the β-hydrogen elimination followed by reductive elimination. Jørgensen [83,84] and co-workers reported Cu(II)-catalyzed highly enantioselective cross coupling of 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene and glyoxylate. The reaction conditions were 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene (1.5 mmol) and ethyl glyoxylate (1 mmol) as the substrates, (SP-4–2)-[(4 R,4′R)-2,2′-(1-methylethylidene)bis[4,5-dihydro-4-phenyloxazole-κN 3]]bis(1,1,1-trifluoromethanesulfonato-κO)-Cu (10 mol%) as the catalyst, and dichloromethane (1 mL) as the solvent. The diene was obtained in 50 % yield and 88 % enantiomeric excess, whereas the hetero Diels–Alder product was obtained in 31 % yield ( Scheme 36). Other dienes and glyoxylate esters were used in the reaction under the same reaction conditions as for 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene and ethyl glyoxylate ( Scheme 37) [83,84]. They reacted 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene with methyl glyoxylate and isopropyl glyoxylate and they reacted isoprene with ethyl glyoxylate. Using 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene resulted in the approximately same selectivity and enantiomeric excess as using 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene and ethyl glyoxylate. Using isoprene also resulted in high enantiomeric excess, albeit the selectivity was low. The configuration of the ligands did not affect the configuration of the products. Wang, Wang, and Duan’s [85] group reported a Ru-catalyzed Heck-like reaction of 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene (1 mmol) and N-chloro-N-(1,1-dimethylethyl)-2-methylbenzamide (0.2 mmol) as the substrates, [RuCl2(p-cymene)] (10 mol%) as the catalyst, 2-phenylpyridine (ppy) (20 mol%) as the ligand, potassium acetate (KOAc) (2 equiv) and H2O (5 equiv) as the base, and 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE) (4 mL) as the solvent under N2 and 20 W blue LED light at 25 °C. The yield of (E)-N-(tert-butyl)-2-(3,4-dimethylpenta-2,4-dien-1-yl)benzamide was 44 % at 25 °C after 24 h ( Scheme 38). The reaction was triggered by the generation of radical species. In contrast, Srivastava’s [86] group aminated the sp3 carbon in dienes. They used a Fe(II) azodioxide complex to synthesize aniline derivatives. For isoprene, the conditions were isoprene (1 mmol) and phenylhydroxyamine (0.25 mmol) as the substrates, tris[diphenyldiazene 1,2-di(oxide-κO)]-iron(II) (T-4)-tetrachloroferrate(II) ([Fe{Ph(O)NN(O)Ph}3][FeCl4]) (10 mol%) as the catalyst, and 1,4-dioxane as the solvent at 60 °C for more than 2 h. N-(2-Methylene-3-buten-1-yl)benzenamine was obtained in 60 % yield. The reaction selectivity of benzenamine versus hetero Diels–Alder reaction products was 85:15 ( Scheme 39). They used other alkyl dienes in the reaction with the same conditions, and the results are shown in Scheme 40 [86]. In the reaction, when the diene and Fe(II) formed an η2-complex, the dienyl amine was mainly obtained, whereas formation of an η4-complex resulted in a Diels–Alder reaction. As a result, N-(3-methyl-2-methylene-3-buten-1-yl)benzenamine was obtained in 56 % yield. The yields of N-(4-methyl-2-methylene-3-penten-1-yl)benzenamine and N-(1-methyl-2-methylene-3-buten-1-yl)benzenamine were 68 % and 70 %, respectively (Scheme 40). The steric hindrance of the 2- and 3-carbons in the diene structures contributed to the selectivity. Related to this reaction, our group [87] also developed an amination with 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene. This reaction used Pd clusters in an oxidative Heck reaction pathway. Typical conditions were 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene (6 mmol) and N-methylaniline (1 mmol) as the substrates, Pd(OAc)2 (10 mol%) as the catalyst, hexamethyldisilane (Me3SiSiMe3) (15 mol%) and 4-nitrobenzoic acid (4-NO2BA) (20 mol%) as the additives, and DMF (0.5 mL) as the solvent at 50 °C for 24 h under air. The desired dienylaniline, N-methyl-N-(3-methyl-2-methylene-3-buten-1-yl)benzenamine, was obtained in 64 % yield ( Scheme 41). To determine the substrate scope, we used other N-methylaniline derivatives in the reaction. The conditions generally remained the same ( Scheme 42) [87]. Monoenyl aniline derivatives were obtained as minor products for all the reactions, and the highest reaction selectivity was > 80 %. We proposed a reaction mechanism involving the formation of Pd nanoclusters based on labeling studies and computing studies ( Scheme 43) [87]. Pd atoms were leached from Pd(OAc)2 and formed Pd nanoparticles, to which 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene and N-methylaniline coordinated. Oxidative cross coupling and dehydrogenation formed the conjugated diene structure, and then the desired dienyl aniline was eliminated. In amination, DMF also functioned as a reductant and protecting species that stabilized the Pd nanoparticles. This amination was a cocktail reaction from the viewpoint of that in situ, Pd existed not only as complex, but also as NPs and NCs. The reaction was applied to polymerization of N-methyl-N-(3-methyl-2-methylene-3-buten-1-yl)benzenamine (1 mmol) with azobis(isobutyronitrile) (3 mol%) as a radical initiator at 75 °C for 24 h under Ar. The yield was 57 % and the cis:trans ratio was 68:32. The product’s 5 % weight-reduction temperature (T d5) and glass transition temperature (T g) were 321 and 163 °C, respectively ( Scheme 44) [87]. In general, sp3 carbon in isoprene and 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene has lower reactivity than sp2 carbon in them because the sp3 carbon has only C–H single bonds. Therefore, to obtain conjugated dienes whose sp3 carbon was functionalized, 1,3-dienes used in the discussed reactions underwent functionalization of the sp2 carbon and a new carbon–carbon double bond were formed at the alkyl branch near the functionalized carbon. In many discussed cases, halides were not used as the substrates and inexpensive center metals were used such as copper and iron. Those are advantages from the other discussed reactions. 3 Conclusions According to the studies in this review, Heck reactions are the main approach to the substitution of conjugated dienes, although cross-metathesis reactions are also used to produce conjugated dienes. Many of the reactions gave medium yields using 1,3-butadiene, isoprene, and 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene because of the simple structures of the substrates or the charge imbalance. Simple structures have small steric hindrance, which causes low selectivity. Functional groups, such as aryl groups, change the charge imbalance and can change the positions of δ+ and δ− charges. Therefore, from the perspective of the substrate scope, functionalized dienes could be upgraded under the same conditions as simple dienes. Consequently, I expect achievement of a one-pot reaction to product feedstocks for highly valued drugs or of important functionalized polymer that include C–C double bonds from simple and inexpensive 1,3-dienes like 1,3-butadiene, isoprene, and 2,3-dimehyl-1,3-butadiene. coredata.dc:description: Conjugated diene structures are important as feedstocks for many organic reactions. Therefore, development of efficient syntheses of conjugated diene compounds is desirable. This review introduces selective functionalizing reactions to 1,3-butadiene, isoprene, 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene with various metal catalysts, ligands, and types of reactions. To overcome difficulties of controlling reactions, Heck reactions with Pd or Ni catalysts and metathesis cross couplings with Grubbs catalysts are mainly used. Focused on ligands, phosphines, 1,5-cyclooctadiene, imidazoline derivatives are frequently used. As a plausible mechanism, formation of π-allyl complexes is concerned as an initial step, especially when palladium is used. Then, as an intermediate, η2-π-allyl metal are formed. At last, reductive elimination undergoes and the desired compounds are obtained. Reaction mechanisms are concerned by labelling experiment or isolation of intermediates in most examples. In addition, in most reactions, results of substrate scope that not only 1,3-butadiene, isoprene, 2,3-dimethyl-1,3-butadiene are used are depicted. Besides, several applications of functionalized dienes are introduced. As a result, synthesized dienes are converted into (hetero)cyclic compounds, polyenes, enyl ketones. Overall, diene is considered a useful starting material for addition reactions such as polymerization, telomerization, and annulation and functionalizing dienes is expected to facilitate the efficient synthesis of organic compounds with complex structures by upgrading simple 1,3-diene.
